comment.author: 19185411@N00
comment._content:
I love looking back in time via photos like this.  What a different world they had back then, one I would have loved to been a part of.

Of course there was no Flickr back then. :)

comment.author: 50282184@N00
comment._content: Max - No offense, but I think you are more of a ball cap guy, rather than derby or top hat.

comment.author: 99217767@N00
comment._content:
Wow, look at the hats!  I think everyone has hats...  

Great photo...

comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: Vice President of the United States James Sherman died on Oct 30, 1912, at age 57, while serving as VP of the United States (President Taft was in office). He died during the presidential re-election campaign (won by Woodrow Wilson) according to Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_S._Sherman

comment.author: 52027278@N00
comment._content: I need a hat like that! I went to a private school that had uniforms involving shirts and ties every day. Then I worked in jobs needing the same. Now I have a job where I make a lot more money with casual attire. I like casual much better. My great grandfather wouldn't come to meal in his own home without a tie on. To each generation their own!

comment.author: 12103981@N03
comment._content: Looks like this is the funeral of James Sherman, 27th Vice President of the United States. Died Oct. 30, 1912, Utica, New York. www.britannica.com/presidents/article-9067318

comment.author: 80428132@N00
comment._content: What a fantastic photo. Damn, do they look dapper. Not THAT'S how one dresses up for a black-tie event!

comment.author: 22057333@N04
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called ONLY SC, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group. Outstanding photo find! I so agree with rmcarrier1 I recently did some research for a website I am working on, www.tuxedos.sc, and there's an article called: Tuxedos, Ascot and Cufflinks: "How To Dress and Act in "Black Tie" - also, "Know How To Dress and Act For Black Tie Events - Tuxedo Guidelines For the Proper South Carolina Gentleman". it pointed out that "dressing for dinner" at one time (not so very long ago) was NOT an option. Really cool photograph to go along with my new found appreciation of the what it means to go "Black Tie".

comment.author: 66847065@N00
comment._content: Much more class distinction in those days with hats as an indicator. Note the toppers, bowlers and yes, there is even a cap. (I would have been a cap person)

comment.author: 20787264@N00
comment._content: to wander outside without a hat was anathema... basically admitting extreme poverty...
